content.description: A bold two bolt lead or most people toprope from the chain anchors rappelling from Harry Daley. A challenging face climb on true 10b territory, follow some larger ramps up to the first bolt, then smear and look carefully for the next few holds to the traversing crack, finish at the bolts. Could be TR with just one 60m rope but Harry Daley rap takes two ropes.
content.location: On Monday Morning Slab, the slab left of the finger crack that starts Harry Daley. Requires a 3rd class scramble up about 100 feet through various ledge systems, then two great routes with Harry Daley and Variation on a Theme.

content.description:
This climbs the right-facing corner, which forms the right-side of Monday Morning Slab, for two pitches.

There has been considerable rockfall in this area over the past several years.
content.protection:
Pro to 3".

Be sure to place gear high (i.e. not in the back of the corner) and use long slings. This will minimize rope drag and keep the rope clear of loose sections.

Pitch 1 is just doable with a 60m rope, pitch 2 is at least 67m.

The top of pitch one has two pairs of bolted anchors. The good, ASCA bolts are about 20 feet left on the large ledge, and have rap rings.

As originally climbed, this route was done in 4 pitches. Even today, this would minimize rockfall from rope management issues. Bring a helmet if you value your noggin!

content.description:
This climbs the left facing corner that forms the left side of Monday Morning Slab, for two pitches.

There has been considerable rockfall in this area over the past several years.

climbs.name: Monday Morning Slab, Harry Daley Route

content.description: Considering that I always have 10-15ft left on my 70m (~225ft) rope at the second anchor (after linking both pitches), there's no way it's anywhere close to 300ft. It is even a stretch to say it's 215 ft, 210 ft for the whole route (even w/ the traversing nature) is much more accurate.
content.protection: 1-2 up to 3.5", depending on your ability
content.location:
Scramble up to the first ledge by the dead tree. Next, move left along the ledge until you see some nice slab/scramble moves on better rock closer to the base of the climb.

Also, for descent, you can rappel on two 60 meter ropes from the first anchors down to that first ledge. Traverse west to the dead tree and scramble down.

-

bmdhacks

With a 70m rope, you can link the pitches and still have rope to spare at the anchors. Two single-rope raps with a 70m will get you down, but just barely with rope stretch on P2.

content.description:
This is a variation of the second pitch of the "Harry Daley Route".

Climb a crack that goes up then curves left, 20' left of the second pitch of "Harry Daley".

Can rappel to the Harry Daley chains with a 60m rope.

There has been considerable rockfall in this area over the past several years.

climbs.name: Coonyard Pinnacle
climbs.fa: Bill Amborn, Joe McKeown and Rich Calderwood 9/60  FFA Chuck Ostin and Frank Sacherer 1961

content.description:
This is the route that started it all on GPA.  It is named for Yvon Chouinard though he was not associated with the climb.

Pitch 1(5.9) - reach up and grab a pocket and mantle up.  This is the technical crux.  Climb up to a small ledge and belay.

Pitch 2(5.8) - climb up the right side of the ledge then up past a bolt to a small pinnacle with a bolt and belay.

Pitch 3(5.9) - traverse left to a two-bolt anchor.

Pitch 4(5.9) - this pitch used to be one of the scariest pitches on the apron featuring 40' of unprotected 5.8/5.9 climbing, but a bolt has been added over the years which has tamed it a bit.

Pitch 5(5.6) - climb up a short, right facing dihedral to the top of the pinnacle.
content.protection: Bring a set of stoppers and cams up to 2" to supplement the bolts.
content.location:
Start this route from the top of Monday Morning Slab.

Three double rope rappels will get you back to the top of MMS.
